meta.description: The SME business health check & investment readiness report is based on a set of 146 weighted questions over 9 categories. While it is a self-assessment, to get a holistic and realistic overview it is suggested to "score" on the conersvative side and not of estimate your capacity and capabilities.

thankyou_screens.title: Congratulations on completing the assessment. Your detailed results will be emailed to you soon.

Thanks for completing this typeform
Now *create your own* — it's free, easy, & beautiful

welcome_screens.title: Welcome to TheSMEFriend medium sized business self-assessment

fields.title: The medium & large Business Health Check & Investment Readiness report is a set of 165 double-weighted questions in 10 categories (business model, strategy, marketing, sales, HR, finance, IT, risk, operations, investment readiness).
Let's start by getting your contact details so we know where to send the report?
First name
Last name
Phone number
Email
Company
BUSINESS MODEL (Part 1/10)

properties.description: Everything starts with the business model. It's the outline of how your business will operate and make money. It highlights how you will deliver value to customers. There are thousands, millions of business models, each as individual as the entrepreneur. For established businesses, it serves as the basis for developing financial forecasts, setting milestones, and setting a baseline for reviewing your business plan.

fields.title: What is the problem you are solving?

choices.label: What do you mean by this question?
I have a general idea of the problem my business is solving.
I know what problem my business is solving but I haven't written it down.
I'm clear of the problem my business is solving.

fields.title: Who is your customer and how well do you know them?

choices.label: Anyone who buys from me is a customer.
I know who my customers are and my business is organised to meet their needs.
I have conducted search to further understand my customers.
I conduct regular customer research and modify my proposition to my customers appropriately.

fields.title: What are the critical success factors?

choices.label: I have no idea what the critical success factors for my business are.
I have an idea of what the most important things in my business are, but I'm not 100% sure.
I know what the critical success factors are, but I don’t know what I can do with this knowledge.
I'm very clear what the critical success factors are and I put a big effort into making sure I address each appropriately.

fields.title: What will it take to make this happen? What is your strategy for success?

choices.label: The business is not going forward / growing.
I don't have a strategy, but it just kind of works.
I know what I need to do and have some notes to remind myself.
I know who my key partners are, what resources I need and the market opportunity. I have a business plan with an implementable roadmap outlining all I need to do to achieve success.

fields.title: Who are the competition?

choices.label: We know who competitors are but don’t actively research them.
We informally keep a watch on competitors to see what they are doing but there is limited documentation or sharing of such information.
We formerly watch what our competitors do. This is done on an ad hoc basis and there are gaps in our knowledge.
We systematically keep a regular update on what our competitors are doing. This includes their product / service range, pricing, promotions, key accounts etc.

fields.title: STRATEGY & PLANNING (Part 2/10)

properties.description: Even when you have achieved a relative level of success you can never sit back and relax. Business requires constant reinvention to keep moving forward. Fresh ideas, new service models and, novel processes are part of the job description for a CEO / founder in a dynamic market place. Your business journey needs a staged approach and a strategy is the process of identifying, articulating and executing on opportunities to increase competitive advantage.

fields.title: How often do you gather market intelligence i..e competitors, suppliers, customers, licences etc?

choices.label: Market knowledge gathering is disorganized, unstructured and ad hoc.
Market knowledge is informal and solely relies on understanding of the local economic conditions and trends.
The gathering of market intelligence is organized and regular.
A specific person is in charge of conducting regular structured market research, both of the domestic market and of global trends.

fields.title: Does the process of market intelligence gathering incorporate customer research?

choices.label: We don’t actively gather any customer feedback, just what we hear word of mouth.
The business reviews existing sources of secondary information to get a broad picture of customer demand.
We do some primary research to understand our customer desires, wants and needs
Regular customer satisfaction surveys and focus groups are conducted. This is cross analysed with secondary research, competitor research and transactional data.

fields.title: What planning and regulatory or licensing approval processes do you follow?

choices.label: The regulatory / licensing impact of new products and services is not considered.
There is no systematic process of handling the necessary steps and coordinating required inputs from relevant departments.
We follow all necessary steps though often leave it to the last minute to get approval and which delays launching of the product or service.
We rigorously understand all regulatory and licensing issues. We have internal capacity and support from the board of directors so that we are compliant.

fields.title: Do you do market studies / understand market dynamics i.e. customer demand, to support the business strategy?

choices.label: We have little understanding of market dynamics.
The business has a limited understanding of the market place and does ad hoc studies.
We do regular market studies but have incomplete knowledge.
We do regular studies and have good knowledge on customers, competitors, suppliers, regulators etc.

fields.title: Can you describe your vision and mission statement? What are the objectives?

choices.label: Our vision and mission is currently not explicitly stated.
Our vision and mission is broad and generic. It does not translate into actual business practices.
The mission statement, customer values, ethical standards and business vision are clearly stated and agreed between the board and senior management.
Mission statement, customer values, ethical standards and business vision are clearly stated and agreed between the board and senior management and communicated with staff and customers.

fields.title: Do you have a strategy articulated? If yes, please describe it?

choices.label: There is no strategy document. Our strategy consists of various incoherent and unaligned documents.
The strategy is expressed in terms of broad objectives such as: market position, introduction of new activities or customer segments, fulfilment of a public good etc.
Strategic objectives are expressed in terms of market share, growth and priority target segments.
The strategy is expressed in how to become more customer centric. There are specific activities how to achieve this

fields.title: Are all employees aware of the vision, mission, strategy and objectives?

choices.label: We have not articulated the vision, mission, strategy and objectives
The vision, mission, strategy and objectives is only important for senior management to know about.
We share the vision and mission with all staff. The strategy is only important for senior management.
The whole company and customers know the vision, mission and general direction of the business. As appropriate, selected staff know greater or lesser details as required for their jobs.

fields.title: Do you have a business plan?

choices.label: No. We don’t have time or expertise to write a business plan.
We had a business plan from some years ago but we don’t look at it.
We have a 3 year business plan but it is now out of date / things have changed a lot since it was written.
We update the business plan on an annual basis.

fields.title: Who developed your financial plan?

choices.label: We don’t have the time or expertise to write a financial plan.
We have a plan but the assumptions are not realistic.
We have a plan with good assumptions but it out of date.
The financial plan is an integral part of the business plan. Assumptions are verified and the plan is updated on at least a 6 monthly basis.

fields.title: Do you have an investment roadmap or prioritization matrix?

choices.label: There is no apparent prioritization or roadmap for investments.
There is no consensus on which goals deserve the highest prioritization.
Investments have been made but no formal prioritization activity has taken place.
The investment roadmap is based on our customer understanding, strategic objectives, financial capacity and market dynamics.

fields.title: Do you have an implementation roadmap?

choices.label: The strategy is isolated. There is a gap between what is said and day-to-day business. Implementation is neither identified nor addressed.
There is a roadmap, but the business works in silos each department doing their own thing.
We have a roadmap but it quickly becomes outdated and not followed. Events overtake plans.
The roadmap identifies critical processes, people and investments. It highlights the need for intentional collaboration and is flexible and adaptable for future innovation.

fields.title: Do you have a Board of Directors?

choices.label: No. There is no need for a BOD / it would be an unnecessary expense.
We have a BOD but on paper for registration / licensing purposes only.
We have a BOD and who meet on an ad hoc basis, this primarily to fulfil company duties rather be active in holding management to account and providing guidance.

We have a BOD that meets on a quarterly basis and which holds the senior management to account. They provide very useful guidance and expertise. When appropriate, they also help open doors for the business.

fields.title: Do you have any strategic partners?

choices.label: No. We are fine to work singularly.
We only work with those that are needed, but in a supplier / customer type relationship.
We see the value of strategic partners and have had some discussions but to date don't have any formerly agreed partnerships.
We actively seek partners who can add value to our business and thus increase our proposition to the customer.

fields.title: Do you get any support from Business Development Service (BDS) providers?

choices.label: What does a BDS provider do?
I see them advertising their services but I don’t think the servcies they offer will help build the business.
I sometimes go to trainings or receive consultancy, but this is normally paid by someone else. I have nothing to lose. I would be willing to pay for such support .

I paid a monthly subscription (or equivalent) to a BDS provider. They help us strategically move forward whether on marketing, being investment ready, developing a business plan or any other area of support.

fields.title: Are you part of any business networks, associations, or similar?

choices.label: No. There is no need / benefit being part of such organisations.
We see the potential of being a member but we have not yet joined any networks.
We are a member of an association but not active.
We are a member of a number of associations / networking groups. This is an invaluable forum for making contacts, getting industry related information, going to trainings and business development.

fields.title: MARKETING (Part 3/10)

properties.description: Before making a purchase, the customer will evaluate the benefits, features and attributes and combined with price, quality and availability, decide if it meets their overall requirements and expectations. It is for this reason, that marketing “creates the environment” to make a sale and can be considered the brain of the business. It coordinates all other departments to get the product or service to the customer in such a way that their expectations are met. Thus, customer research is vital as it will allow the business to understand customer’s requirements and build a customer profile for different market segments.

fields.title: What customer research tools do you use?

choices.label: We don’t do any formal customer research. We rely solely on customer feedback in person.
We only do online or phone call questionnaires.
We do face to face quantitative (questionnaires) and qualitative (interviews and focus groups).
We do questionnaires and focus groups, map the customer journey, have mystery shoppers, analyse data etc.

fields.title: How often do you do customer research?

choices.label: We don’t do any formal customer research. We rely solely on customer feedback in person.
We do ad hoc customer research.
There are annual customer satisfaction surveys.
Customer research is an ongoing process. It happens regularly and through different mediums i.e. phone, in-person, online etc.

fields.title: Do you have a baseline survey on customer satisfaction so that you can analyse positive or negative changes?

choices.label: We don’t have a baseline survey on customer satisfaction.
We did a baseline survey but it did not specifically address customers satisfaction.
We did a baseline survey on customers satisfaction but we haven’t done any follow up work or analysis.
We did a baseline survey on customers satisfaction and incorporated the findings into product / service design, our processes, communication messaging etc.

fields.title: Do you segment you current and potential customer base?

choices.label: Our customers are homogenous.
We know what customer segmentation is but we don’t actively segment our customer base.
We segment our customer base and have a generic profile for each customer group.
We segment our customer base and have a detailed profile for each type of customer group based on primary market research and analysis of data.

fields.title: When launching a new product or service, do you have a distinct value proposition for each segment?

choices.label: We use a standard process when launching a new product or service and which doesn’t include segmenting the customer base.
We realise that the customers have different challenges but we don't differentiate in our marketing.
We have segmented our customers but we use similar marketing materials for all due to cost considerations.
The value proposition and marketing activities are distinct for each customer segment. We differentiate the marketing approach and distribution channels.

fields.title: Do you develop a marketing and communication plan for the different segments?

choices.label: What is a marketing and communications plan?
We have a marketng plan but we don’t adjust it for different products or segments.
We do what we can in terms of personalising our marketing for different segments or products, but our resources are stretched thin.
We develop a specific marketing and communications plan for each segment and/or product. We understand the importance of making sure the right messages go to the right audience.

fields.title: How would you classify your product development process?

choices.label: There is limited attempt to innovate and no specialized employee in charge of product development.
Product innovation is rare.
The development of new products capable of satisfying customer demands has been identified as a priority by the business.

The business permanently assesses the adequacy between the product offer and customer’ demand e.g. through focus groups or customer satisfaction surveys. This is managed by a product development specialist.

fields.title: How do you orientate customer needs to new products and services?

choices.label: There is limited attempt to innovate and no specialized employee in charge of product development.
New products are mostly treated as silos without proper integration into the business’ overall systems and processes.
An employee is responsible for product development. Their work is based on customer market research.
Product development is conducted by a specialized team that includes experience of human centred design and prototyping principles.

fields.title: Who manages product development, rollout and management?

choices.label: There is no product development manager.
Product development is incorporated in the commercial department.
An employee splits their time between managing product(s) and other roles.

We have an experienced product development person / team. They understand how to gather the business requirements, pilot and/or soft launch the product and then manage the product once commercially live.

fields.title: Does the product manager coordinate the development of the product or service with other departments to bring the product or service to market?

choices.label: There is no integration between departments
Coordination with other departments. (accounting, IT/technology, audit, risk etc.) takes place on an ad-hoc basis.
Coordination with other departments takes place on a regular basis, but the transition from "project" to commercial is not well defined.

The product manager cooperates efficiently with other units to ensure new products are integrated smoothly in the business' internal processes and systems. This starts with identifying the business requirements.

fields.title: How do you create customer awareness

choices.label: We rely solely on word of mouth
We use some marketing collaterals i.e. leaflets, posters etc.
We rely on social media and occasionally do an event or go to a trade show.
We have a fully integrated Above The Line (ATL) Below The Line (BTL) and Though The Line (TTL) marketing and communication plan.

fields.title: What marketing channels to you use, how and for what?

choices.label: Marketing channels are limited to traditional routes i.e. flyers.
More than one marketing channels is used to inform customers.
A range of marketing channels are used i.e. both traditional and digital marketing.
A range of marketing channels are used. The effectiveness of each marketing channel is analysed, the communication and channel tweaked accordingly.

fields.title: Do you have a loyalty program?

choices.label: There are no customer strategies on how to drive customer acquisition & retention.
There is no comprehensive understanding of how and why customers engage with some products and not others.
We have designed a loyalty program to drive customer acquisition and retention but it is not yet operational.
We have an active loyalty program which is closely monitored with specific KPIs.

fields.title: What digital marketing do you do?

choices.label: We only use traditional media i.e. leaflets, flyers, radio etc.
We have tested digital media but we don’t have the necessary skills to invest and transfer marketing activities from traditional media channels to digital.
We increasingly use social media to argument traditional media.
We have a digital marketing department which use multiple channels and develops a range of innovative communication packages ranging from podcasts to WhatsApp business.

fields.title: How interactive is your SMS service?

choices.label: We don't use / have no need for SMS.
We Push SMS only.
We Pull SMS only.
We Push and Pull SMS.

fields.title: Do you use a USSD (shortcode phone menu) or have an app?

choices.label: We do not have an app and feel USSD is outdated.
We are currently developing an app.
We use USSD as our primary method of communication as this is accessible from all phones.
We use USSD as our primary method of communication and have an app for richer content.

fields.title: How do you set your prices?

choices.label: Gut feeling on what is appropriate.
We have the same prices as our competitors.
We analyse our cost assumptions and revenue requirements.
We analyse our cost assumptions and revenue requirements, the competition and, customer price elasticity.

fields.title: Do you know how price senstive your customers are?

choices.label: What is price sensitivity?
We see a change in demand (when we change our prices) but we haven't done any research.
We have done some customer research on prices, but not an analysis.
We have done an analysis on customer price sensitivity / elasticity and have made changes accordingly to get the best mix of profit versus incresing sales..

fields.title: How well do you know the competitive landscape?

choices.label: We know who competitors are but don’t actively research them.
We informally keep a watch on competitors to see what they are doing but there is limited documentation or sharing of such information.
We formerly watch what our competitors do. This is done on an ad hoc basis and there are gaps in our knowledge.

We systematically keep a regular update on what our competitors are doing. This includes their product / service range, pricing, promotions, key accounts etc. Where we see they are doing something well and which fits our business model, we imitate.

fields.title: How do you monitor customer satisfaction?

choices.label: We don’t monitor customer satisfaction.
We get regular reports from our sales team.
We get regular reports from our sales team. We do ad hoc customer satisfaction surveys thru our call centre.
We cross analyse customer feedback from multiple sources and make adjustments to product design, training, communication etc. as appropriate

fields.title: Do you have a Net Promoter Score (NPS)?

choices.label: What is a net promoter score?
I have heard of a NPS but have not yet implemented it.
We are in the process of collecting the NPS.
We firmly believe the benefits of collecting the NPS. We use the analysis in many of our decision making processes.

fields.title: Do you get staff feedback?

choices.label: We have no formal mechanism for staff feedback other than through meetings.
We solely rely on staff customer operational reports or informally through trainings and the like.
We regularly collect staff feedback through questionnaires.
We get regular and systematic staff feedback through multiple channels i.e. social media, WhatsApp, push / pull SMS, SurveyMonkey etc.

fields.title: SALES (Part 4/10)

properties.description: The rise of e-commerce means customer expectations have shifted. They are now used to getting what they want, when and where they want it, and usually at a competitive price. There are no longer content with waiting. Ensuring high-quality levels of pre-sales, actual sales and aftersales service is essential to build customer loyalty no matter the size of the business, sector, geography or whether you operate from a brick-and-mortar shop or online. It is for this reason why it is important to analyse the customer journey and identify pain points which need to be corrected.

fields.title: Is the customer lifecycle mapped?

choices.label: What is a customer lifecycle?
The interaction between the business and its customers is informally structured.
We know that the customer lifecycle maps the different stages a customer goes through but we have not mapped it.
The customer lifecycle is formally mapped and covers the following stages: a) reach, b) acquisition, c) development, d) retention, e) advocacy.

fields.title: Can you describe the customer lifecycle?

choices.label: The steps a customer goes through interacting with the business and using its different products and services has not been defined.
Managers are aware of the customer’s steps such as considering, purchasing, using, and maintaining loyalty .
Even though customer lifecycle exists and covers the most important touch points, it is not comprehensive and largely seen as an academic exercise.
The customer lifecycle covers all touch points between the business and its customers. We map the customer lifecycle for the launch of all products and services.

fields.title: Is the customer lifecycle regularly updated?

choices.label: The steps a customer goes through interacting with the business has not been defined.
The customer journey is known but mapping of the interaction between the customers and the business has not been done.
Even though customer lifecycle exists and covers the most important touch points, it is not comprehensive and largely seen as an academic exercise.
It is regularly updated.

fields.title: Do you have different processes and objectives for various stages of the customer journey?

choices.label: There is no mapping of the customer journey.
The principal touch points are defined for some products and services but there is no comprehensive understanding of how, why, when the customer engages with the business.
The customer journey is mapped for most products and services and demonstrates a good understanding of the touch points and how customers interact with the business.

Understanding is comprehensive. Each stage contains a mix of pull and push services: pull services do not need much marketing, Push services need customer education and marketing but add unique value.

fields.title: What sales channels do you have?

choices.label: We only have one (physical or online) sales channel.
We have a physical location and a website.
We have a physical location, a website, an app and other digital channels.
We have a physical location, a website, an app and other digital channels. We also sell through third parties.

fields.title: Do you make sales calls by phone, in-person or online?

choices.label: We don’t do sales calls.
We do ad hoc cold calling.
We have a “hot list” of potential customers.
We have an organised process to develop new business.

fields.title: Are your channels harmonised when launching a new product or service?

choices.label: There is no coordination between the various channels when launching new products or services.
We launch all new products and services through all channels.
Customer testing is performed prior to full rollout across all channels so customisation can be made where needed.
We conduct Human Centred Design for all channels prior to any launch and which allows us to customise per channel while also having a harmonised strategy.

fields.title: How do you measure the profitability of each channel?

choices.label: We do not measure profitability per channel, but measure profitability per product or service.
We do ad hoc research on channel profitability.
We measure each channel's profitability but there is no specific channel manager or specific KPIs.
We measure each channel. The channel manager has specific KPIs which they have to attain.

fields.title: Do you use QR codes?

choices.label: We don’t know what a QR code is.
We see the benefits of QR codes but we have not yet started to implement them into our business.
We have started a QR code pilot.
We have seen higher efficiency and a more satisfying consumer experience since integrating QR codes.

fields.title: What payment channels do you have?

choices.label: We only accept cash or cheque.
We accept debit card payments.
We accept debit and credit card payments.
We accept cash, credit / debit cards, PayPal, digital money etc.

fields.title: What consumer protection policies do you have in place?

choices.label: We don’t have any consumer protection policies.
We follow the legal requirements.
We have multiple channels to help consumers troubleshoot.
We provide information on terms and conditions, FAQs, complaint / redress mechanisms, fees etc. We follow consumer protection best practice guidelines.

fields.title: What after sale support do you give customers?

choices.label: There is no requirement for after sale support.
We provide support only at the time of the sale.
We provide support as and when needed.
We have staff available 24/7 to support the customer in any challenge they have.

fields.title: What after sale support do you give customers?

choices.label: There is no requirement for after sale support.
We provide after sale support only at the time of the sale.
We provide after sale support as and when needed.
We have staff available 24/7 to support the customer in any challenge they have.

fields.title: Do you have post-purchase services?

choices.label: We haven't considered post purchase services.
We know it is important but haven't implemented any such services yet.
We realise returns and refunds are a critical part of the customer experience. We do our best but we have not put any specific processes in place.
We realise returns and refunds are a critical part of the customer experience. This is a priority for us as we want return customers.

fields.title: Do you have a ticketing system for customer complaints?

choices.label: There is no ticketing system.
There is no ticketing system but there is a process to handle complaints / enquiries.
There is a ticketing system but it is not fully functioning.
There is a ticketing system with internal resolution timelines. A manager is held accountable for performance.

fields.title: How can customers contact you?

choices.label: There is no general purpose number a customer can call.
There is a phone number that customers can call, but there is no specific staff to respond.
We have staff to answer the phone, respond online etc. as needed.
We have multiple channels for customers to contact us: email, phone, WhatsApp etc. We have a fully staffed call centre with customer satisfaction KPIs.

fields.title: Do you have suggestion boxes or similar?

choices.label: There are no suggestion boxes.
There are suggestion boxes but no formalized processes on how to react to them.
There are suggestion boxes and reports are made on the feedback.
There are suggestion boxes / online forms etc. and feedback is acted on and recorded.

fields.title: How do you ensure good customer service?

choices.label: If the customer doesn’t like what we do they can go elsewhere.
We follow what we have found on the internet about customer service.
We ensure staff are well-trained and that staffing levels are sufficient. A friendly smile goes a long way.
Staff are well trained and have excellent product knowledge. We provide 24/7 customer support where possible and have an optimal checkout experience.

fields.title: Do you personalise your services?

choices.label: No, that is to expensive.
We have thought about it but decided it wasn't needed.
We provide additional services and care to our biggest customers.
We recognize that we should "reward" repeat customers and make new customers feel special.

fields.title: Do you know who your repeat customers are?

choices.label: No
Yes, we know who our repeat customer are from in-person interactions.
We have customer relationship manager software.
We have a loyalty program linked to our customer relationship management systems.

fields.title: What Key Performance Indicators do you have for customer support?

choices.label: We don’t record customer interactions.
A log of interactions is made but not reported.
Key Performance Indicators are recorded and presented in Excel.
Key Performance Indicators are monitored through real time dashboards. We made this investment so that we can constantly improve the customer experience.

fields.title: HUMAN RESOURCES (Part 5/10)

properties.description: No matter the size or shape of your business, everything starts and ends with your team. Your role as a CEO / founder is to create a set of rules and metrics that guide employees how to do their job. Your human resources compensation and support framework should motivate the team and keep them accountable for the effort and quality of their work. Having a sense of urgency, dynamism, is an important concept. Remember, passion is intangible and can’t be measured in numbers but it is one of the most critical parts of a business. A passionate and motivated workforce is the key to success.

fields.title: Is the management structure appropriate Is there  a suitable mix of experience?

choices.label: The management structure means we are uncoordinated.
We follow what the internet advises.
We have gone thorugh a few changes. The current structure is the best option.
We have been through a number of iterations and the current structure is the best option. However, we are always looking to improve and adapt to market conditions.

fields.title: Is there an appropriate diversification of skillsets and handover protocols?

choices.label: In many departments there is only one person. They have some skills and experience but there are not that senior. Even so, If they leave we have a serious problem.
Although most departments have more than one staff member, only the head has a bird's eye overview. There is a risk if they leave.
At least one person other than the Head of Department has a good overview of the overall business and their department’s role in it.
The management of the business is balanced with clear leadership. Managers are experienced and handover plans are in place should they leave / become ill / take holiday.

fields.title: Is there suitable external support from professionals i.e. accountants, lawyers, auditors etc?

choices.label: We don't have any external support though we need it.
We don't need external support.
We hire consultants or outsource activities when needed i.e. accounting. We have  identified where we don’t have sufficient internal capacity or capability.
All our requirements are covered "in-house". However, on occasion we get external support for a second opinion or if there is a very specific challenge / opportunity.

fields.title: Do you have inclusive policies on issues of gender, disability, sexual orientation etc?

choices.label: We have not considered inclusive issues.
We understand inclusive issues but we don’t have capacity or experience to implement them.
We take inclusivity of staff very seriously and have all appropriate policies and procedures in place.
We take inclusivity for both staff and customers alike very seriously and have all appropriate policies and procedures in place.

fields.title: How do you manage internal communications?

choices.label: Internal communications is mostly or fully uncoordinated.
We have a WhatsApp group, but this is mainly used for sharing jokes rather than business related news.
We have a staff member who is responsible for internal communications so that the team is aware of what is happening.
We have a staff member who is responsible for internal communications. We also have a way for rapid communication. This can range from a WhatsApp group (or similar) to an intranet platform.

fields.title: Is ownership / accountability clear and appropriate for all staff?

choices.label: Ownership and roles and responsibilities is unclear.
There is a general assignment of responsibilities to individuals but it is not clear to everyone what this entails.
Ownership and definition of role is clear through job descriptions and individual key performance indicators.

Ownership and definition of role is clear through job descriptions and individual key performance indicators. More overly, there is clarity on the role of each department / person and the expectations of the manager.

fields.title: How do you measure your change culture in response to customer demand?

choices.label: We measure standard Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) but not the impact it has on the customer.
We measure consumer impact but in an ad hoc fashion.
We measure impact in a formal way on the basis of standard KPIs.
We have a set of KPIs that measure consumer impact, speed and responsiveness to changes in customer demand.

fields.title: What have you done to empower employees?

choices.label: There is no / little opportunity for employees to challenge "business as usual".
We enable employees to come up with recommendations which are then managed by more senior managers.
We empower employees through forums to debate / challenge what was done in the past.
We actively empower employees to challenge a "business as usual" culture.

fields.title: Is there a project manager (or similar) who works on strategic initiatives' across the business?

choices.label: Cross business activities are mostly or fully uncoordinated.
Strategic initiatives are managed centrally by the CEO.
There is a project manager who handles their own portfolio of activities, but it is not always clear what they do.
The project manager is fully integrated in the organizational chart. Their role and responsibilities and reporting lines are clear.

fields.title: Do you follow a top down, a bottom up, or somewhere in between form of management?

choices.label: We have a rigid top down formal approval process.
We enable employees to make changes but within the framework of a formal approval process.
We provide employees with limited freedom to do "what’s right" with a limited formal approval process / control mechanism.
We give employees autonomy and a freedom to do "what’s right" without a formal approval process. We accept that mistakes might/will happen​.

fields.title: What support do the executive team give their juniors?

choices.label: Most executive managers do their job well but have little interest in those they manage.
Some executive managers have experience of managing others.
Most executive managers have experience of managing others and we are giving them support to build this competence.

Leadership realizes the potential of all employees to strengthen the business. All managers have strong man-management experience in a variety of environments and know how to get the best out of their team.

fields.title: Are there regular / weekly executive meetings to coordinate activities?

choices.label: There are no regular meetings to coordinate activities.
Coordination across the business takes place largely on an ad-hoc basis.
Coordination between senior managers takes place on a regular basis, but there is no formality i.e. sharing of meeting notes and action points.
The CEO coordinates proactively with their leadership team to ensure smooth outcomes. This is supported by meeting notes and updating the implementation plan on a regular basis.

fields.title: Does the business rely on key people and what would happen if they were unavailable?

choices.label: The business works in silos with no systematic knowledge exchange. The key person risks are elevated and there is no back-up options.
Dropout of key people would create significant risks of disruption and knowledge loss.
Dropout of key people would create significant risks of disruption and knowledge loss.
Key person dependencies are moderate and largely manageable due to developed handover protocols.

fields.title: How is the sales team managed?

choices.label: The front line sales team largely works independently.
There are supervisors who manage the sales team, but it is unclear how they are managed.
There are regional / head office managers who manage the supervisors.
There is a clear line of reporting from sales team / all field operations to leadership.

fields.title: Do you have the right employee "mix"?

choices.label: We don’t know our staffing gaps.
We have identified major staffing gaps and are in the process of recruitment.
We have the a majority of the right staff with only minor gaps.
We have the appropriate mix of staff from retail manager and cashier to buyer and inventory controller (or equivalent).

fields.title: What process do you use to recruit staff?

choices.label: We recruit based on other staff / personal recommendations.
We develop a basic job description and hold interviews.
We develop a detailed job description and advertise via papers / the internet / recruitment agencies and then hold an interview to find who is available.

We develop a detailed job description and advertise via papers / the internet / recruitment agencies and then hold interview(s)  to find the candidate with the best skills, experience, and personality to fit the job.

fields.title: How do you set your salary / compensation packages?

choices.label: Gut instinct.
We look at what we can afford versus the profit margin of the company.
We do a detailed analysis / financial plan to understand what we can offer.
We define the company's compensation philosophy and then analyze the job market to define the total compensation package.

fields.title: What (if any) benefits do you offer your staff?

choices.label: We don’t provide any benefits.
We provide the statutory minimum requirements.
We give the same standard benefits that most employers in our sector do.
Benefits are part of our company's compensation philosophy. We use a business analysis to define which benefits to offer and which provide greatest value to our staff.

fields.title: What training policies do you have in place?

choices.label: Staff receive on the job training.
We sometimes get outside trainers to train the staff.
We morally support staff to get trained / certified on their own volition and give them some time allowance.
We give a time allowance and financially support staff to get trained / certified on their own volition.

fields.title: Is staff turnover high?

choices.label: Staff change frequently.
It is difficult or expensive to replace staff so we keep the same people even if they are underperforming.
The turnover is moderate and the hand-over process is formally organized and structured. Replacement is generally quick.
The overall staff turnover is reasonably low.

fields.title: Are staff suitable qualified / certified?

choices.label: Most staff do not have or need certification.
There is a lack of formal certification.
The majority of staff are well trained and sufficiently competent / certified.
Most staff not only understand their jobs well but also have the appropriate certification / qualification.

fields.title: FINANCE (Part 6/10)

properties.description: The finance department records inflows and outflows of monies. It is a major contributor to determining the financial viability and sustainability of the business. As well as recording the daily movement of money, there is need for financial planning and which, includes cashflow analysis, profit & loss, and balance sheet recording. When making decisions, it is important to use quantified and realistic assumptions based on upto date costs and revenue forecasts. This will help both near term projects and implementation of the longer-term business plan.

fields.title: Do you use cost / benefit analysis when deciding on investments?

choices.label: No systematic process is in place to analyze investments.
Investments are analyzed but do not encompass all relevant impact (profit & Loss, cash flow etc.).
Cost benefit analysis are performed but lack depth and/or are not systematically integrated in decision making.
Quantified and realistic cost-benefit analyzes are made for all investments prior to decision-making. This helps the leadership come to a consensus.

fields.title: How are financial analysis made?

choices.label: Customer and revenue assumptions underlying the decisions are not available or incomprehensible.
Integration of financial planning is incomplete or exhibits deficiencies.
Financial planning is only conducted for the near term.
Financial planning is integral for both near term projects and implementation of the longer term business plan.

fields.title: How are cost and revenue assumptions made?

choices.label: Cost and revenue assumptions underlying decisions are not available or incomprehensible.
Cost and revenue assumptions underlying the business are not realistic.
Cost and revenue assumptions underlying the business are largely realistic but not regularly updated.
Underlying assumptions are based on up to date and realistic costs and revenues.

fields.title: Do you provide credit to customers?

choices.label: No, it is not appropriate for our business.
We provide credit, but don’t have good record keeping of our debtors.
We provide credit as part of our sales strategy but have unsustainable levels of debtors.
Providing credit is part of our value proposition to increase sales and customer loyalty.

fields.title: Do you have credit terms from suppliers

choices.label: No, it is not appropriate for our business.
We take credit but we are getting into problems due to the terms.
Taking credit is the usual way we do business.
Taking credit helps us with cash flow due to slow-paying debtors.

fields.title: Do you provide credit to customers?

choices.label: No, it is not appropriate for our business.
We provide credit, but don’t have good record keeping of our debtors.
We provide credit as part of our sales strategy but have unsustainable levels of debtors.
Providing credit is part of our value proposition to increase sales and customer loyalty.

fields.title: What ability do you have to raise internal funds?

choices.label: We are not operationally or financially sustainable.
We are moving towards operational sustainability but are far from financially sustainable.
We are operational but not yet financially sustainable.
We are operationally and financially sustainable and can raise funds internally as need be.

fields.title: Are external sources (investors / banks / grants) of finance available if needed?

choices.label: There are no external financial resources (investors, banks or grants) available.
There are few external resources available.
There are external resources though not sufficiently available.
Sufficient external resources are available.

fields.title: What financial services can you access?

choices.label: We borrow solely from family and friends.
We use microfinance / credit union / cooperative type services. This is fine for now, but the range of services is limited.
We use a range of formal financial services from insurance and credit to equity and debt. I get all financial services I need.
We use a bank but their rates are not competitive and their services limited. We have been with them a long time and don't know if we should change.

fields.title: What non-financial servcies do you access?

choices.label: What are non-financial services?
Non-financial services such as training are provided but we have not taken advantage of them.
We have downloaded their mobile banking app and which we use sometimes, but have not really investigated it.
We make the most of all the services the financial institution offer. We mainly use internet banking.

fields.title: Are there appropriate financial systems in place?

choices.label: There are no appropriate financial systems.
There are some financial systems in place.
Most appropriate financial systems are in place.
All appropriate financial systems are in place.

fields.title: Does Two Factor Authentication (2FA) / 2 signature rule apply for all payments?

choices.label: There is no operation which requires 2FA / two signatures.
Staff have limited access to the financial systems.
Only a few operations in the financial system need 2FA.
All sensitive operations need 2FA.

fields.title: Have standard operating procedures been developed for reconciliation?

choices.label: We have no reconciliation procedures.
We do manual reconciliation.
We have an automatic process for reconciliation.
We have well defined reconciliation procedures that address failures, exceptions etc.

fields.title: Have risks associated with fraud been identified and processes put in place to mitigate these risks?

choices.label: We have not identified any fraud risks.
We know there are fraud risks but we do not know how to mitigate against them.
We have identified fraud risks and have a mitigation strategy in place including written processes.
We have identified fraud risks, put in place appropriate controls to red flag the fraud and, have appropriate processes to mitigate against the risks.

fields.title: ICT (Part 7/10)

properties.description: Business of all sizes are increasingly reliant on technology, whether this is core to their operations or in a support role to make processes more efficient and transparent. In many businesses, big and small, digital resources are not being leveraged to their full potential. For example, to enable ‘just-in-time’ delivery, Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) or digital payments and social media. IT can also can help to guarantee product quality, a smooth and robust logistics process, or to safeguard the confidentiality of a new product or innovation throughout the entire chain. Central though is the need for a Management Information System (even if Excel or similar) to manage the business and record customer interactions and financial flows.

fields.title: What IT or  Management Information System (MIS) specific policies do you have?

choices.label: The business has no or limited MIS policies. Enforcement of these policies is not systematically applied.
The business has some IT policies and enforcement is applied.
The business has IT and MIS policies clearly describing roles of all systems' users.
The business has up-to-date IT and MIS policies complying with international standards.

fields.title: What security measures are there and how are they enforced?

choices.label: It is not possible to trace operations performed in the MIS and other key systems.
We have internally done an audit of our security measurements and enforcement.
The IT system has been independently audited for security measures / failings / enforcement
The IT system is regularly audited for security measures / failings / enforcement.

fields.title: Are staff activities on the MIS logged?

choices.label: It is not possible to trace all operations performed in the MIS.
It is possible to trace activites on the MIS but not in a sufficient manner i.e. it is difficult or not possible to distinguish "maker / checker" for all activites.
Systems user activities are logged and sensitive operations monitored. Users are registered in a directory.
Systems user activities are logged and sensitive operations monitored. Users are registered in a directory. Any suspicious activity is automatically red-flagged.

fields.title: What firewall or anti-virus systems are in place?

choices.label: No antivirus nor firewall is deployed.
Antivirus and firewall are partially deployed (e.g. on managers devices).
Firewall and antivirus are deployed on all devices.
Firewall and antivirus are deployed on all devices and regularly updated.

fields.title: What password security do you have and how is it enforced?

choices.label: Password policies are not known to staff nor enforced.
Password policies are enforced.
Strong password policies are enforced.
Strong password policies are used and automatically require users to frequently update theirs.

fields.title: What software do you use, is this licensed and, how is it updated?

choices.label: Most software is expired or not supported by the vendor.
Only up-to-date software is used.
Only legitimate and up-to-date software is used across the business.
Software updates are pushed by centralized system. Updates are automatic and regular.

fields.title: What backup policies do you have for key information like customer data, financial records etc?

choices.label: Basic backup of vital information is made on flash disk or we email it to ourselves every now and then.
A limited business continuity process has been laid out but never rehearsed properly.
The backup policies are detailed and include most critical information across systems.
The backup policies are detailed and include all critical information across systems.

fields.title: Do you have a business continuity plan and, are regular tests conducted?

choices.label: There is an absence of a business continuity plan.
The business continuity plan is drafted but staff are not aware of it.
The business continuity plan is clearly drafted and maintained. Staff are informed about it.
The business continuity plan is clearly drafted and regularly rehearsed e.g. server intentionally switched off during business hours.

fields.title: Do you have an offline protocol?

choices.label: We have no offline protocol.
We work offline but the process is not documented.
Business continues as normal with records uploaded manually once the system is working again.
Business continues as normal with records uploaded automatically once the system is working again.

fields.title: Are systems scalable?

choices.label: Systems scalability is unknown.
There is limited knowledge with regards to scalability.
Systems are scalable and expected to support more load.
Systems are tested as scalable. Bottlenecks are identified and mitigation measures known.

fields.title: Do you have a roadmap to bridge the gap between legacy and digital operations?

choices.label: There is no digital transformation roadmap or strategy to bridge the gap.
The digital transformation strategy is isolated and the gap between legacy and digital business is neither identified nor addressed.
We have a strategy for digital operations but have not started implementation as we don’t know the investment cost.

The roadmap identifies critical processes between legacy and digital work. It outlines the need for intentional collaboration. The strategy moreover ensures flexibility and adaptability for future innovation.

fields.title: How are third parties handled i.e. are there Service Level Agreements (SLAs) for vendors?

choices.label: Vendor faults such as, delayed or defective deliverables, are not identified or followed up on.
Vendor contracts are basically checked and there is no formal review loop. There is no systematic follow-up on delays or defects.
The deliverables review process is formalized but is basic and involves limited coordination with other actors (business departments, IT department etc.).
Our Service Level Agreements clearly define a.) type of service; b.) reliability of service; c.) responsiveness; d.) supervision of service delivery; e.) reporting channels; f.) consequence

fields.title: Were Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) developed for data handling?

choices.label: We do not have data handling procedures
We have some data handing procedures
We have data handling procedures from data collection, data in transit, data at customer, archiving and disposal
We conducted a privacy impact assessment and have data handling procedures from data collection, data in transit, data at customer, archiving and disposal.

fields.title: Is your data collection digital or paper-based?

choices.label: Data collection is completely paper-based.
Data is collected with paper and pen and entered manually by the back office.
Data is mainly digitalized and digital tools deployed.
We have an end-to-end digital process.

fields.title: What is the quality of your digitally collected data?

choices.label: No digital data is collected.
Digital data is collected but is purely text-based and the system is not able to perform any verifications.
The system performs simple verifications of text-based data.
Data entry is auto-verified. There is collection of rich data such as Pictures, GPS based geolocation and biometrics. Free text fields and purely declarative data is avoided if possible.

fields.title: What tasks does the database perform?

choices.label: The database is incomplete and queries are not possible.
The database is comprehensive and allows for simple queries in real time.

Data is stored in a comprehensive and query able database that is able to automatically pull data from other applications, such as the financial and human resource information system. It can generate ad hoc reports

Data is stored in a comprehensive and query able database with some data history. The database is able to automatically pull data from other applications, such as the financial and human resource information system.

fields.title: How do you ensure that the data you are keeping is safe?

choices.label: There are no internal rules on data safety, security and protection.
Data safety, security and protection guidelines are on paper but staff are unaware or not sufficiently trained.
Staff are aware and trained on data safety requirements.
A data safety framework is in place. In case of a breach there is a well-defined set of standards and tools to ensure data privacy and security.

fields.title: How do you ensure business continuity in case of problems i.e. a natural disaster?

choices.label: There is no way to recover data in the case of a natural disaster or similar problem.
A second site hosts backups, but the backup process is slow and manual.
A Disaster Recovery site hosts backups which would allows fast recovery (i.e. real time minus 5 minutes).
A full-fledged Disaster Recovery site instantly takes over in case of problems.

fields.title: Do you have Business Intelligence software and analytics?

choices.label: We do not have business intelligence software or systems.
We do ad hoc performance reporting but it is not formalized or digitized.
We are starting to implement business intelligence initiatives but it is at an early stage.
We  monitor multiple information points of our customers so that we can do analysis and develop appropriate products / channels / services / marketing campaigns etc.

fields.title: Do you have Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software and analytics?

choices.label: We do not have Customer Relationship Management software or systems.
We do ad hoc customer research but it is not formalized or digitized.
We are starting to implement Customer Relationship Management initiatives but are at an early stage.
We monitor multiple information points of our customers so that we can do analysis and develop appropriate products / channels / services / marketing campaigns etc.

fields.title: Do you have reporting dashboards?

choices.label: Reports are done by pen and paper and manually entered into Excel.
There are Excel based reports but only senior management has access to them.
There are dashboards but they have limited functionality and accessibility.
All staff are able to see the reports which are important for their job. There are different access levels / information matrix, so staff only see reports relevant to them.

fields.title: Do you use Machine Learning (ML) and Artificial Intelligence (AI)?

choices.label: We know nothing about this technology.
We see the benefits of data analysis but we have not yet started to implement it.
We have started a pilot to use these technologies.
ML and AI helps us analyze large volumes of data quicker and in a more efficient and targeted manner.

fields.title: Do you use a distributed ledger and blockchain technologies?

choices.label: We know nothing about this technology.
We see the benefits of immutable data but we have not yet started to implement it.
We have started a pilot to use this technology.
We recognise the benefits of blockchain and data management for greater transparency, reducing fraud, improving customer management.

fields.title: Do you have technical experts for new and innovative technology?

choices.label: We have no technical experts.
We rely on the vendor / partner to provide their technical experts.
We hire technical consultants.
We have in-house capacity with experts in their respective fields.

fields.title: RISK & AUDIT (Part 8/10)

properties.description: All companies face risks whether these are operational, finanical, legal or reputational. As such, inadequate risk management is not compatible with effectively protecting your business and especially in the face of a changing risk landscape i.e. though the increase use of technology and fluctuating levels of customer demand. Therefore, it is vital to identify, evaluate, mitigate and monitor risks.

fields.title: Is there a risk management function? Is it independent from other departments?

choices.label: The business has no risk management function.
The business has a central risk management function, but it is still rudimentary in terms of human resources and scope of activities.
The risk management function is independent.
The risk management function is well-adapted to the business overall and has proven to be an effective developer and coordinator of adequate risk management solutions.

fields.title: What is the capability of the risk management unit?

choices.label: Risks are owned and managed by the respective heads of department.
The risk department does not yet play an active and effective role in risk mitigation but rather documents the changes in risk levels.
The risk department has the capability to coordinate risk inputs from different departments. However, it lacks resources, expertise and experience.
The risk department has the capability to coordinate risk inputs from different departments and has the appropriate resources, expertise and experience.

fields.title: Is there an operational risk database?

choices.label: The business does not have a systematic process of identifying, managing and monitoring operational risks.
The business has an operational risk register or database but does not regularly review it.
The operational risk database is reviewed at least once a year but largely on the basis of existing products and processes.
The operational risk management process contains a proactive, forward-looking approach to identifying new risks and developing new procedural solutions and tools to mitigate them.

fields.title: Is there systematic or periodic collection of operational risk incidents?

choices.label: The business does not have a systematic process of identifying, managing and monitoring operational risks.
The business has an operational risk register or database but does not regularly review it.
The operational risk database is reviewed at least once per year but largely on the basis of existing products and processes.
The Operational Risk Management register is reviewed regularly to ensure all aspects of the business are suitably covered.

fields.title: Is there proactive identification of new business risks?

choices.label: We only know of existing risks.
The risk database is updated regularly but retroactively.
We have started to develop a framework for identifying new risks.
The risk team conducts regular audits to identify and document new risks.

fields.title: Is there an autonomous internal (or external) audit function?

choices.label: The business has no audit department.
The business uses an external auditor.
The internal audit function is fully independent from management.
The independent internal audit function possesses a team with diversified skills and which is technically and operationally qualified. We also have an external auditor.

fields.title: Does the audit team systematically monitor activities?

choices.label: Audits or checks are conducted sporadically but not carried out independently from the business owners.
Audits are mainly compliance-based.
We have started to develop an awareness for audit challenges but have not yet revised our operations to reflect new risks.
Audit reports show a high degree of analytical quality and are regularly updated.

fields.title: OPERATIONS (Part 9/10)

properties.description: Operations management is the optimization of business processes through planning, organizing, and supervising human resources, raw materials, tasks, and projects in order to improve productivity and deliver a world-class product or service. Good operations ensure the right inventory levels, facilitates sales, delivers orders to your customers, improves customer loyalty, tracks financials and helps in making good decisions to drive growth. As such, businesses must make their operations as efficient as possible, noting, if it is not, excessive cashflow will be tied up in back-end processes, sales will be lost and costs will be higher than they could otherwise be.

fields.title: How do you manage your supply chain and purchasing?

choices.label: We use a manual system, largely relying on pen and paper and then data entry.
We have basic technology to assist us but mistakes happen often.
Automation is part of our investment plan. We will implement this in the next 12 months.
We made an investment in the software and hardware to automate our processes and we see significant cost and time savings as well as a better service to our customers.

fields.title: How do you manage warehousing, order fulfilment and inventory management?

choices.label: We use a manual system, largely relying on pen and paper and then data entry.
We have basic technology to assist us but mistakes happen to often.
Automation is part of our investment plan. We will implement this in the next 12 months.
We made an investment in the software and hardware to automate our processes and we see significant cost and time savings as well as ultimately a better service to our customers.

fields.title: How do you manage picking, packing and delivery?

choices.label: We use a manual system, largely relying on pen and paper and then data entry.
We have basic technology to assist us but mistakes happen often.
Automation is part of our investment plan. We will implement this in the next 12 months.
We made an investment in the software and hardware to automate our processes and we see significant cost and time savings as well as ultimately a better service to our customers.

fields.title: How do you manage order warehousing, and order fulfilment? inventory management?

choices.label: We use a manual system, largely relying on pen and paper and then data entry.
We have basic technology to assist us but mistakes happen to often.
Automation is part of our investment plan. We will implement this in the next 12 months.
We made an investment in the software and hardware to automate our processes and we see significant cost and time savings as well as ultimately a better service to our customers.

fields.title: Does customer demand change during the day, week, month, year?

choices.label: I don’t know.
It changes but we haven't done an analysis.
It changes and we do some rudimental demand analysis for planning purposes i.e. if there are holidays, what the weather is like etc.
We know the high and low points of customer demand. We plan accordingly  so that we never have to much or too little, this leading to additional costs in the former and lost sales in the later.

fields.title: Are there cross-departmental systems and collaboration?

choices.label: The business works in silos.
There is some collaboration but this comes down to the individual rather than systems or culture.
All departments work well together but in a fairly manual manner.
Process automation has enabled all departments to work in synchronicity.

fields.title: Have you used technology to streamline processes and procedures?

choices.label: SOPs were produced at a time when operations were largely paper-based.
SOP are unsystematically reviewed at departmental level with no involvement of other units (risk, audit).
SOPs are regularly updated with meaningful inputs from all departments.
We use a Customer Management and Business Process Management systems (or similar) to ensure the greatest operational efficiency.

fields.title: Do you do regular systematic updates of your processes and procedures?

choices.label: We do not do regular or systematic updates of the SOPs
We do updates on an ad hoc basis.
We do regular updates but not in a systematic way.
SOPs are updated regularly. All appropriate staff are trained to familiarize themselves with the updates.

fields.title: Do you have rule-based automation to get more orders out the door faster?

choices.label: No. That sounds good! Tell me more!
We want to automate but we don’t know what to invest in.
Automation is part of our investment plan. We will implement this in the next 12 months.
We made an investment in the software and hardware to automate our processes and we see significant cost and time savings as well as ultimately a better service to our customers.

fields.title: Do you provide suitable technical training to your staff?

choices.label: There are no trainings.
There are periodic trainings.
There are ad hoc trainings but no certification.
There are systematic trainings so staff can do their job effectively, efficiently and safely. We make sure they are properly certified.

fields.title: Do you have an induction process to suport the new hire in their role?

choices.label: What is an induction process and why do we need one?
It is intutitve what the new hire needs to do, but we give them a quick briefing and on the job training.
We make sure they are fulled trainined to do their job.

We have a systematic induction process to make sure the new staff knows what they do, who the report to, any risks asscoaited with their role, timelines, who will be the key people they work with etc.

fields.title: Are staff trained in health and safety?

choices.label: What is health and safety training?
Some staff have limited understanding of health and safety. We have a first aid station.
All staff are aware of health and safety issues.
All staff are well trained in health and safety, this is part of their induction process.

fields.title: Is your business easily accessible?

choices.label: This is not something we have really considered.
Our options were limited so did the best we could.
We know what we wanted to do and have a good plan, but we need the appropriate investment to realise our plans.

We have taken careful consideration in planning accessibility ranging from infrastructure like car park etc. for physical locations to the online equivalent of great SEO, user interface and navigation.

fields.title: Is you shop front (physical or online) optimised?

choices.label: We copy what everyone else does.
We have a marketing manager to work on this, but they are not very experienced.
We have an experienced team that gives their best efforts.
It is easy for customers to find what they want, whether that is good Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) and design for the website, or shop layout.

fields.title: Is the checkout / purchase process quick and easy?

choices.label: This is not something that we have really considered.
We think so, but have not done any customer research to confirm this.
The checkout / purchase process is quick and easy
We have an omnichannel strategy. It is a seamless customer experience whether they make the purchase online, in person, via phone or at an agent.

fields.title: INVESTMENT (Part 10/10)

properties.description: You want a potential investor go, Wow! when they see your pitch deck. However, businesses must be investment ready to secure external funding. Therefore, management teams must understand their growth plans and financing needs to ensure that new funding supports, rather than hinders, their path to growth. Further, they must understand how their business will be perceived by investors and be equipped to negotiate. So, it is important to take a step back and understand what investors will be looking for so that you can be confident that you will have all the information they are looking for.

fields.title: Do you have strategic milestones?

choices.label: We haven't really discussed strategy as a founder team.
We agree on the strategy but have no specific milestones.
We have specific milestones for the next 18 months but don’t yet have an implementation and investment plan of how we are going to achieve them.
We have agreed specific milestones for the next 18 months. We have a detailed implementation and investment plan of how we are going to achieve them.

fields.title: Do you have an exit strategy?

choices.label: We haven't talked about this yet.
The discussion has started but we have different opinions.
We have an agreed high level plan but not yet the details of how we are going to exit the business.
We have a clear and agreed exit strategy. All founders have the same goals. We regularly talk about the exit strategy so that we put in place the plans and investment to make it possible.

fields.title: What is the Environmental, Social & Governance (ESG) impact of the business?

choices.label: What is an ESG framework?
We have heard of ESG and seem some presentations, but don’t know what it means for us.
We have been trained on ESG and are in the process of developing suitable processes.
We have ESG frameworks, a set of guidelines that help us manage our ESG commitments. They provide direction to the business, and we report on the ESG to the board of directors.

fields.title: Do you have a mix of experience in the founder team?

choices.label: I'm a single founder.
Our expertise is centered around our product / technical knowldge. We don't know much about other areas of the business.
Our founders have a mix of expertise but some areas of the business are not covered.
The founders have a stong mix of expertise and experience and which covers all angles we need for our business.

fields.title: Do you have a Board of Directors

choices.label: No. There is no need / it would be an unnecessary expense.
We have a BOD but on paper only for registration / liscensing purposes only.
We have a BOD and who meet on an ad hoc basis, this primarily to fulfil company duties rather than be active in holding management to account and providing guidance.

We have a BOD that meets on a quarterly basis and which holds the senior management to account. They provide very useful guidance and expertise. When appropriate, they also help open doors for the business.

fields.title: What is your market position and how can you protect it?

choices.label: What is a market position?
Competition is a fact of life and we will fight all the way.
We regularly do market research to gage customer expectations. We think we are safe.
We have anticiapted threats. We monitor out Net Promotor Score. We have a marketing strategy for agressively regaining customers if needed.

fields.title: Are there barriers to entry for new entrants?

choices.label: There are no barriers to entry. Anyone potentially could do our business.
The main barrier to entry is economies of scale and which we have overcome.
There are barriers in relation to regulation, access to channels, and start up costs.
There are significant barriers to entry from technical expertise and experience to start up costs and partnerships.

fields.title: How will your product or service offering evolve?

choices.label: We don't know, we don't have a product roadmap.
We have a high-level view on major product improvements but without cost estimates.
We know the products / services we will add and estimates of how much it will cost.
We have a 3 year product roadmap. It covers which features / products / services to add, what they will cost and, the go to makret straegy for deliverng them.

fields.title: What level of traction / historic sales do you have?

choices.label: We have a positive feeling that we are heading in the right direction but no data.
We have some data but no analysis.
We have done some basic analysis on Excel.
We have business intelligence and customer relationship management software which gives us imperical data on demand trends.

fields.title: Who are your competitors and what makes your product unique?

choices.label: What is a Unique Selling Proposition?
We concentrate on our business rather than what competitors are doing.
We have a long list of competitors but we have not analyzed their businesses to know where our USP and differentiation points are.

We know who our direct competitors are and what substitution products are in the market. We analysed the market and highlight our competitive advantages and USP in our marketing and communication materials. This allow us to defend our position.

fields.title: What do you know about your target market?

choices.label: We haven't done any research yet.
We have defined our target market but have not done the analysis on market potential.We have defined our target market but have not done the analysis on market potential.
We rely mainly on secondary data, but from that we have a detailed understading of the market.
We conducted primary research. Combined with secondary research we have a clear view on market potential. We have segmented our potential customer base and have a plan for each (segment).

fields.title: What is your customer acquisition process?

choices.label: We take what we can get.
We know what our customer understanding shortfall is.
We know specifics of target segments and have a list of customer acquisition channels.
We have a go-to-market strategy for each segment / product. We use a cost benefit analysis (or similar) whenever we make strategic acquisition decisions.

fields.title: Do you have a financial plan?

choices.label: We are working on it.
We have a basic plan with some revenue lines and some cost details. We can calculate break even.
We have a 3 year cashflow, profit & loss and balance sheet projections based on market assumptions.
We have a 3 year plan with conservative, forecast and aggresive scenarios. We know our monthly burn and capital injection requirements. We can explain our assumptions and show our forecast KPIs.

fields.title: Have you considered other financing options other than an investor?

choices.label: No. We are only intersted in investors.
We contacted the bank for a loan and waiting to hear back from them.
We contacted the bank for a loan and are waiting to hear back from them. We have also applied for a grant
We have a clear investment plan to grow the business. We are looking at various financing options and analysing which is the best fit for the next 2 years.

fields.title: What are your capital needs?

choices.label: As much as we can get.
We have a rough idea but need an investor to guide us.
We have a 3 year cash flow, profit & loss and balance sheet projections based on market assumptions.
We have a 3 year plan with conservative, forecast and aggressive scenarios. We know our monthly burn. We can explain our assumptions and show our forecast KPIs.

fields.title: How have you come up with a value of your business?

choices.label: We don't know what the value of the business is.
We looked on the internet for how to value our business.
We have used a well known valuation model.
We know our valuation range and which has been independently verified. We have benchmarks. The results fit our expectations of how many shares we are willing to offer investors.

fields.title: Have you created a list with the most suitable investors for your company?

choices.label: Not yet.
We know some angel investors on a personal basis.
We are going through investment forums to identify the best fit.
We have contacted investors who have a record of investing in similar business, in the same industry and level of business maturity.

fields.title: Are all appropriate due-dilligence documents prepared for potential investors?

choices.label: What documents are needed?
We have a pitch deck.
I have drafted an email and designed a teaser.
We have detailed documentation for pre due-diligence.
